text.text: How does it work
ERB is a toolkit containing 5 chapters that guide you through a process for building equitable resilience in your community (see
). Depending on the goals you come up with, you will proceed through the chapters in different ways.
Project planning.
Get a core team together to set your goals for your ERB process and put together a project plan.
Community engagement.
Carry out a social network analysis and begin the outreach that is the foundation for inclusive participation in ERB workshops.
Hazard and social vulnerability identification.
Hold community workshops to identify hazards from disasters and climate change from and figure out who is made most vulnerable to these hazards, why, and how.
Equitable resilience assessment.
Use indicators and local knowledge to measure how the built, natural, and social environments affect resilience and equity in your community.
Taking action.
Hold community workshops to identify how you're going to take action to address resilience and equity needs.
What do you need to get started?
- Interest and support from your office and other local constituencies in strengthening resilience and equity
- 4-6 people who can join your core team
- Resources and capability to facilitate 2-3 community workshops (virtual or in-person)
- The first step is to create an ERB project
from the landing page
What outputs will you get?
Depending on the path you take through the ERB, you will generate:
- Ch. 1: Project plan, team storytelling
- Ch. 2: Social network analysis, stronger relationships, and community empowerment around resilience
- Ch. 3: Hazard identification slides, social vulnerability assessment table, community storytelling
- Ch. 4: Resilience indicator measurements and visualization
- Ch. 5: List of action items for building equitable resilience, documentation of what you've accomplished
